item.title: Biden says Putin made a 'big mistake' on New START treaty
item.dc:creator: Caroline Kenny and Summer Concepcion and Phil McCausland
item.description: President Joe Biden condemned Russian President Vladimir Putin’s suspension of his country’s involvement in the last remaining arms control treaty with the U.S.

media:content.media:text: In image from video released by Russian Defense Ministry Press Service on Oct. 26, 2022, a Yars intercontinental ballistic missile is test-fired as part of Russia's nuclear drills from a launch site in Plesetsk, northwestern Russia.

media:content.media:text: Putin speaking in Moscow on Feb. 21, 2023.
media:content.media:description: Russian President Vladimir Putin delivers his annual state of the nation address Tuesday at the Gostiny Dvor conference center in central Moscow.

item.title: Buttigieg visits East Palestine following train derailment and chemical spill
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Shabad and Liz Brown-Kaiser
item.description: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg is visiting East Palestine, Ohio, to view the site of the train derailment that led to a spill of toxic chemicals into the community.

media:content.media:text: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg visits the site of the derailed train in East Palestine, Ohio, on Feb. 23, 2023.
media:content.media:description: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg visits the site of the derailed train in East Palestine, Ohio, on Feb. 23, 2023.

item.title: Jan. 6 rioter who threatened Rep. Ocasio-Cortez sentenced to 38 months in prison
item.dc:creator: Dareh Gregorian and Daniel Barnes
item.description: Garret Miller, a Jan. 6 rioter who threatened Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez on Twitter after the Capitol attack, was sentenced to 38 months in prison Wednesday.

media:content.media:credit: U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia
media:content.media:text: Garret Miller.
media:content.media:description: Garret Miller.

item.title: Supreme Court hears lawsuit claiming Twitter aided and abetted terrorist attack
item.description: The Supreme Court seemed skeptical of a lawsuit that alleged Twitter aided and abetted the spread of militant Islamist ideology. NBC's Laura Jarrett reports on questions the justices had for both sides during oral arguments.

media:content.media:title: Supreme Court hears lawsuit claiming Twitter aided and abetted terrorist attack
media:content.media:description: The Supreme Court seemed skeptical of a lawsuit that alleged Twitter aided and abetted the spread of militant Islamist ideology. NBC's Laura Jarrett reports on questions the justices had for both sides during oral arguments.

item.title: Supreme Court deciding if Big Tech companies are responsible for what users see online
item.description: The Supreme Court is deciding whether or not Big Tech companies can be sued for personalizing what you see online. NBC News’ Laura Jarrett has more details on the case.

media:content.media:title: Supreme Court deciding if Big Tech companies are responsible for what users see online
media:content.media:description: The Supreme Court is deciding whether or not Big Tech companies can be sued for personalizing what you see online. NBC News’ Laura Jarrett has more details on the case.

item.title: Biden makes defiant address on Ukraine ahead of Russian invasion anniversary
item.description: President Biden made an address ahead of the one-year anniversary of Russia’s war in Ukraine, offering an unmistakable message to Russian President Putin that “Ukraine will never be a victory for Russia.” NBC News’ Kristen Welker has more details on how Americans are feeling about the conflict.

media:content.media:title: Biden makes defiant address on Ukraine ahead of Russian invasion anniversary
media:content.media:description: President Biden made an address ahead of the one-year anniversary of Russia’s war in Ukraine, offering an unmistakable message to Russian President Putin that “Ukraine will never be a victory for Russia.” NBC News’ Kristen Welker has more details on how Americans are feeling about the conflict.

item.title: Supreme Court hears case over holding Google liable for videos with harmful content
item.description: The Supreme Court seemed unsure about a lawsuit that sought to hold YouTube, and their owner Google, liable for hosting videos promoting violent militant Islam and suggesting those videos through their algorithm. NBC's Laura Jarrett reports on how justices' questioning during lengthy oral arguments.

media:content.media:title: Supreme Court hears case over holding Google liable for videos with harmful content
media:content.media:description: The Supreme Court seemed unsure about a lawsuit that sought to hold YouTube, and their owner Google, liable for hosting videos promoting violent militant Islam and suggesting those videos through their algorithm. NBC's Laura Jarrett reports on how justices' questioning during lengthy oral arguments.

item.title: Putin gave Biden a $12k desk and pen in 2021, one of many gifts foreign leaders gave the president that year
item.dc:creator: Mike Memoli
item.description: Vladimir Putin gifted President Joe Biden a distinctive Russian desk set valued at $12,00 after their meeting in Geneva in June 2021.

media:content.media:text: President Joe Biden sits next to a bowl of Irish shamrocks, left, as he has a virtual meeting with Ireland's Prime Minister Micheal Martin on St. Patrick's Day on March 17, 2021.
media:content.media:description: President Joe Biden sits next to a bowl of Irish shamrocks, left, as he has a virtual meeting with Ireland's Prime Minister Micheal Martin on St. Patrick's Day on March 17, 2021.

item.title: Rep. Scott Perry argues in court against phone search in special counsel's Jan. 6 probe
item.dc:creator: Summer Concepcion and Daniel Barnes
item.description: Rep. Scott Perry, R-Pa., a Trump ally who supported efforts to overturn the 2020 election results, is arguing in court against the DOJ accessing his phone data.

media:content.media:text: Scott Perry during a meeting of the House Oversight and Reform Committee in Washington
media:content.media:description: Scott Perry during a meeting of the House Oversight and Reform Committee in Washington, on Jan. 31, 2023.

item.title: Bankman-Fried charged with hundreds of illegal campaign donations
item.dc:creator: Alex Seitz-Wald
item.description: Embattled cryptocurrency mogul Sam Bankman-Fried directed millions of dollars of illegal campaign contributions to elected officials, prosecutors alleged.

media:content.media:text: Sam Bankman-Fried arrives at court in New York on Feb. 16, 2023.
media:content.media:description: Sam Bankman-Fried arrives at court in New York on Feb. 16.

item.title: West Virginia transgender sports ban halted during appeal
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Transgender athletes in West Virginia can compete in female school sports while an appeal is heard on a state law banning their participation, a divided federal appeals panel ruled Wednesday.

media:content.media:text: Gov. Jim Justice delivers his State of the State address in Charleston, W.Va.
media:content.media:description: Gov. Jim Justice delivers his State of the State address in Charleston, W.Va. on Jan. 11.

item.title: Senators urge DOJ to press Ticketmaster after Judiciary Committee hearing
item.dc:creator: Frank Thorp V and Zoë Richards
item.description: WASHINGTON — The leaders of a Senate Judiciary subcommittee that oversees competition policy and antitrust issues have called on the Justice Department to keep looking into Ticketmaster over concerns that it holds damaging monopoly power after a congressional hearing last month.

media:content.media:text: Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., greets Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah., during the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing titled "That's the Ticket: Promoting Competition and Protecting Consumers in Live Entertainment," in Hart Building on Tuesday, January 24, 2023.
media:content.media:description: Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., greets Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah, in the Hart Senate Office Building in Washington on Jan. 24.

media:content.media:text: Live Nation Entertainment, Inc. President and Chief Financial Officer Joe Berchtold appears before a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing to examine promoting competition and protecting consumers in live entertainment on Capitol Hill in Washington, Tuesday, Jan. 24, 2023.
media:content.media:description: Live Nation President Joe Berchtold at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing in Washington on Jan. 24.

item.title: Steve Bannon sued for nearly $500,000 in alleged unpaid legal bills
item.dc:creator: Summer Concepcion
item.description: A law firm that represented former Trump adviser Steve Bannon is suing him for nearly $500,000 in alleged unpaid legal bills.

media:content.media:text: Steve Bannon outside of federal court in Washington
media:content.media:description: Steve Bannon outside federal court in Washington, on July 22, 2022.

item.title: New photo shows U.S. pilot's high-altitude selfie with Chinese balloon
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Jennifer Jett
item.description: The Department of Defense has released a new photo showing an Air Force pilot flying above the suspected Chinese spy balloon that was shot down over United States territory earlier this month.

media:content.media:text: Image: *** BESTPIX *** U.S. Air Force U-2 Pilot Looks Down At Suspected Chinese Surveillance Balloon
media:content.media:description: A U.S. Air Force U-2 pilot looks down at the Chinese surveillance balloon on Feb. 3, 2023 as it hovers over the United States.

item.title: Ex-member: Proud Boys failed to carry out ‘revolution’
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: WASHINGTON — Proud Boys leaders plotted to violently prevent President Joe Biden from taking office because they were trying to “save the country” from what they feared would be a tyrannical government, a former member of the far-right extremist group told a jury on Wednesday.

media:content.media:text: FILE - Proud Boys member Jeremy Joseph Bertino, second from left, joins other supporters of President Donald Trump who are wearing attire associated with the Proud Boys as they attend a rally at Freedom Plaza, Dec. 12, 2020, in Washington. Bertino told jurors on Tuesday, Feb. 21, 2023, that he viewed their far-right extremist organization as "the tip of the spear" after the 2020 election. Bertino is testifying against former Proud Boys national leader Enrique Tarrio and four lieutenants as part of a cooperation deal with federal prosecutors.
media:content.media:description: Jeremy Bertino, second from left, joins other supporters of President Donald Trump in attire associated with the Proud Boys at a rally in Washington on Dec. 12, 2020.

item.title: Former Arizona attorney general failed to release report disproving election fraud claims
item.dc:creator: Zoë Richards
item.description: Former Arizona Attorney General Mark Brnovich did not release to the public findings from his office that showed a series of 2020 election fraud claims were not backed up by evidence, according to documents released Wednesday by his successor.

media:content.media:text: Mark Brnovich.
media:content.media:description: Mark Brnovich.

item.title: Schumer slams McCarthy over Tucker Carlson's access to Jan. 6 security video
item.dc:creator: Scott Wong and Liz Brown-Kaiser and Rebecca Shabad
item.description: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer said Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s decision to give Jan. 6 security footage to Tucker Carlson “poses grave security risks."

media:content.media:text: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., speaks during a news conference at the Capitol in Washington, Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023.
media:content.media:description: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., at a news conference at the U.S. Capitol on Feb. 2.

item.title: Namibian dancers, president welcome Jill Biden to Africa
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: WINDHOEK, Namibia — Dancers, drummers and Namibia’s president and first lady welcomed U.S. first lady Jill Biden on Wednesday as she opened a five-day, two-country visit to Africa aimed at highlighting the challenges facing women and young people and the food insecurity plaguing the Horn of Africa.

media:content.media:text: Namibian President Hage Geingob Namibia's first lady Monica Geingos and Jill Biden at the State House in Windhoek on Feb. 22, 2023.
media:content.media:description: Namibian President Hage Geingob Namibia's first lady Monica Geingos and Jill Biden at the State House in Windhoek on Feb. 22, 2023.

item.dc:creator: Lawrence Hurley
item.description: The Supreme Court considers whether Twitter can be sued for aiding and abetting militant Islamist ideology in the case of a Jordanian citizen killed by a terrorist.

item.title: Arizona House GOP votes to restrict secretaries of state from overseeing their own elections
item.dc:creator: Summer Concepcion
item.description: The Arizona House on Tuesday voted to make it illegal for the secretary of state to oversee an election in which they are also a candidate.

item.description: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg will visit East Palestine, Ohio, to view the site of the recent train derailment that led to a spill of toxic chemicals.

item.title: Democratic governors launch alliance to protect abortion access
item.dc:creator: Rose Horowitch
item.description: Twenty Democratic governors formed an alliance to defend abortion access following the Supreme Court's June ruling overturning the right to the procedure.

item.title: Mike Pence breaks with Trump on Medicare and Social Security
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Allen
item.description: Former Vice President Mike Pence said cuts to Medicare and Social Security should be "on the table for the long term," differentiating himself from Donald Trump.

item.title: Sen. Jon Tester to seek re-election in 2024
item.dc:creator: Summer Concepcion
item.description: Sen. Jon Tester, D-Mont., announced he will run for re-election, a decision that comes as Democrats look to hold onto their slim Senate majority in 2024.

item.title: Mississippi governor vows to sign limit on transgender care
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Once the bill is signed by Republican Gov. Tate Reeves, Mississippi will become the seventh state to restrict gender-affirming care for transgender minors.

media:content.media:text: Mississippi Gov. Tate Reeves in Jackson on Oct. 27, 2022.
media:content.media:description: Mississippi Gov. Tate Reeves in Jackson on Oct. 27.

media:content.media:text: People protest House Bill 1125, which would ban gender-affirming care for trans children, in Jackson, Miss., on Feb. 15, 2023.
media:content.media:description: People protest House Bill 1125, which would ban gender-affirming care for trans children, in Jackson, Miss., on Feb. 15.

media:content.media:text: A protester holds a poster calling for lawmakers to protect trans children by voting against House Bill 1125, which would ban gender-affirming care for trans children, at the Mississippi Capitol in Jackson on Feb. 15, 2023.
